Chef Rick Ortiz met his wife Ashley in one of the most distinguished places in all of Chicago: Soldier Field. They worked well creatively and soon found themselves in a strong, romantic relationship. With Ashley’s amazing sense of repurposing and Rick’s culinary prowess, the concept of Antique Taco was born. Today they share their passion for hosting parties with friends and family.

Rick & Ashley's restaurant

Antique Taco
Chef Rick's Antique Taco Ceviche recipe

citrus and seafood

when working with seafood, you can marinate portions in citrus rather than chopping it up. the citrus can do all the work. Then you can shred it with a fork after it's done.

rosemary margarita

we put a little spin or our margarita, where we add a little rosemary to the sweetener. plus fresh lime juice, fresh orange juice, salt, and of course, lots and lots of tequila. it adds a little variety and it's very fresh.

table setting with jars

I don't think we ever use a traditional vase for flower arrangements. try a pickle jar, salsa jar or mason jar. cut a few flowers short. try some long. the variety can make the table beautiful.

Q & A

Which Mariano’s do you shop?

Rick: Mariano’s West Loop is our go-to store.

What do you love most about Mariano’s?

Rick: The raw bar. And the cheese selection. The food is so fresh. That’s my draw to going there. Ashley: I love all the sampling. Food is on the mind when you’re here, so it’s kind of nice to sample something.

How often do you have people over for food?

Ashley: I’d say two times a month usually. Rick: If I pick up a little extra food I may invite my cousin or dad.

Do you have guests bring food or do you make it all yourself?

Ashley: We tell them to just bring themselves. They usually end up bringing something to drink. Sometimes people feel intimidated bringing food over to a chef’s house. But it’s silly, because he and I will eat anything.

Who are your culinary influences?

Rick: I’d say my father. He cooked a lot growing up. His main thing was going to the store and only buying what we were going to make that evening. Just to keep it fresh. And that’s what we do to this day.

What’s a good tip for salsa?

Rick: We like to incorporate fresh garlic. Sometimes when your salsa becomes too hot you can add a little bit of fresh garlic and it will tone it down.

What’s the most popular pepper in Mexican cuisine?

Rick: The jalapeño. But I love guajillo chiles. I make a lot of pastes and dry rubs with them. A lot of people put them on meats, but we love to put them on mushrooms.

How do you make your gatherings more memorable?

Ashley: I think we do a good job of making a little takeaway for people. I’m a very crafty person, so I’m always stamping or putting a tag on something. Rick: We might make a spice mix. Ashley: It’s fun to add to the table and fun for someone to bring it home. It’s unexpected and people really enjoy it
